abstract: It’s hard to argue with the results.
snippet: It’s hard to argue with the results.
lead_paragraph: You can tell a lot about a man by how he treats his dogs. My ex-husband called Tilly, our Labrador retriever mix, “pinhead.” He banished her from our bed (while welcoming our other dog) because she lavished affection on me, or so I surmised, and by doing so, he managed to punish us both.

headline.main: Not Saying My Dog Is Cupid, but …
headline.print_headline: Not Saying My Dog Is Cupid, but ...

abstract: Sandra Perez was paying for her own degree while trying to help her sons, but she also needed to get out of her brother’s apartment.
snippet: Sandra Perez was paying for her own degree while trying to help her sons, but she also needed to get out of her brother’s apartment.
lead_paragraph: Chaos reigns at Sandra Perez’s apartment on Staten Island. Visitors are expected, including one loaded with cameras, and the family is rushing to get ready.

abstract: A father wonders why his son and father are such a pair, while he and his father seem like such a mismatch.
snippet: A father wonders why his son and father are such a pair, while he and his father seem like such a mismatch.
lead_paragraph: ON a recent cross-country visit to my parents in California, I came down from my old childhood bedroom, still bleary with jet lag, and was startled by the sound of a boy’s laughter from my parents’ room. I tiptoed to the door and heard my father’s low voice, then more of those high-pitched giggles.

lead_paragraph: When Francis Stephen arrived in the United States from Bangladesh two years ago, his father already had a career plan in mind for him, he said.

abstract: Michelle Wildgen Modern Love essay on ignoring early warning signs of her husband's alcoholism; drawing (M)
snippet: Michelle Wildgen Modern Love essay on ignoring early warning signs of her husband's alcoholism; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: IT was the last night of our honeymoon, and we were making soup with lobster, shrimp and crab -- not a meal for someone who, like me, had been sent to the emergency room by a dish of crab Rangoon two weeks earlier. On this trip, I had eaten a lot of shellfish but no crab Rangoon, and the swelling, itching and rapidly closing throat had not returned. I hoped to continue my luck, but I suspected this new allergy was not as limited as I had hoped.

lead_paragraph: Roma G. is convinced that the good will of a New York Hospital administrator saved her life in 1965. That year, the official, whose name she cannot remember, admitted her to the hospital's psychiatric ward, even though her father could not afford to pay the bills.

lead_paragraph: She lost Joey to asthma shortly before he was to turn 11 — a searing memory for Earline Sierra, who recalls that as her son was having another of his many asthma attacks, “he was talking to me, and he turned blue, and he stopped breathing.”

abstract: Is that cute avatar checking out my avatar? My virtual heart leaps.
snippet: Is that cute avatar checking out my avatar? My virtual heart leaps.
lead_paragraph: I'M 24 years old, have a good job, friends. But like many of my generation, I consistently trade actual human contact for the more reliable emotional high of smiles on MySpace, winks on Match.com and pokes on Facebook. I live for Friendster views, profile comments and the Dodgeball messages that clog my cellphone every night.

abstract: In our 20s, we thought only about the cost of not doing things.
snippet: In our 20s, we thought only about the cost of not doing things.
lead_paragraph: WHENEVER my husband casually says, “Hey, hon, come take a look at this Web site,” I know it’s going to cost me. All of our largest purchases were preceded by my being summoned to his computer in this manner. So, three years ago, when he said this a few weeks before his 40th birthday, I knew it was really going to cost me, and I don’t mean just financially.

headline.main: A Diesel Engine Woke Up Our Marriage
headline.print_headline: A Diesel Engine Woke Up Our Marriage

abstract: This time of year, many people are digging deeper to pay for gifts to make their childrens' day brighter. The charities affiliated with The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are digging deeper to brighten the lives of children year-round.    The donations the Fund receives translates into many kinds of help. For a 3 1/2-year-old boy infected with H.I.V., a program financed by fund provides counseling to deal with the heartbreak. For a group of 10-year-olds, a volunteer's dedication has created a newspaper in which they chronicle their lives    Articles, page 48.
lead_paragraph: This time of year, many people are digging deeper to pay for gifts to make their childrens' day brighter. The charities affiliated with The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are digging deeper to brighten the lives of children year-round.

abstract: The realism of a gritty TV program gives a couple joy in their last moments together.
snippet: The realism of a gritty TV program gives a couple joy in their last moments together.
lead_paragraph: TYRONE and I never watched TV together  at least we didn’t until last fall, when his lymphoma came back. We knew then what we were in for, months of waiting for the injections of Campath to knock down the cancer, and fear that it wouldn’t. We knew there would be many homebound evenings, so I put all five seasons of “The Wire” on my online DVD list.

headline.main: Down to ‘The Wire’
headline.print_headline: Down to ‘The Wire’

snippet: A mother lost her home when the rent rose steeply, and now seeks a less-expensive apartment in which to raise her children.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Veronica Hibbert found herself suddenly alone, raising four children and trying to maintain the family’s home in the Baychester section of the Bronx, all on the small salary of a patient-care assistant at a local hospital. Her husband of 18 years had left, and child-support payments were not forthcoming.

abstract: After a grand mal seizure in March, Nikkiya Simmonds lost all her memories of the last two years, including the birth of her daughter.
snippet: After a grand mal seizure in March, Nikkiya Simmonds lost all her memories of the last two years, including the birth of her daughter.
lead_paragraph: Her memory ravaged by damage done to her brain, Nikkiya Simmonds, 32, returned to an apartment that might as well have belonged to a stranger. It was a cozy dwelling, strewn with cute knickknacks and calming artwork that she was tickled to learn that she had chosen, that she was, indeed, home.

abstract: Among animals, a remarkable gesture of interest wins a mate. In humans, our most useful allure is resistance.

lead_paragraph: A FEW days before I was dumped, I sat in the campus library. It was the eve of my first chemistry exam that semester. Under the dusty lights of the reading room, I was supposed to be studying. Instead, I stared at the cracked screen of my cellphone, waiting for a call.

abstract: The worst thing about bedbugs isn’t the bugs themselves, or even the painful bites. It’s the isolating way others react when you give them the news.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: ''AT least he's good-looking,'' I say to my husband whenever the subject of our oldest son's dating future comes up. And he is good-looking, our son, with his blue eyes, wavy hair, broad shoulders and warm smile. He's also got a deep voice (he works at it) and a gentle manner. It's hard to believe girls won't fall in love with him. And maybe they will.      But he also has autism. When he's tired or sick, he forgets words or uses them incorrectly; often it requires enormous effort just for him to maintain a conversation. It's as if he has no native tongue and essentially has had to memorize our language word by word.
snippet: ''AT least he's good-looking,'' I say to my husband whenever the subject of our oldest son's dating future comes up. And he is good-looking, our son, with his blue eyes, wavy hair, broad shoulders and warm smile. He's also got a deep voice (he wor...

And he is good-looking, our son, with his blue eyes, wavy hair, broad shoulders and warm smile. He's also got a deep voice (he works at it) and a gentle manner. It's hard to believe girls won't fall in love with him. And maybe they will.

abstract: Daniel Jones, the editor of Modern Love, takes a look at his teenager.
snippet: Daniel Jones, the editor of Modern Love, takes a look at his teenager.
lead_paragraph: “She dumped me.” That’s the first line of the first Modern Love column, published on Oct. 31, 2004, and it’s a tale of heartbreak, obsession and regrettable emails. In the 13 years since, more than 670 columns have followed, and while heartbreak and obsession still dominate, regrettable emails have mostly given way to regrettable texts, Instagram posts and Tinder swipes.

headline.print_headline: ‘She Dumped Me.’

lead_paragraph: Dmitriy Frenkel has only one pair of shoes. He wears them in August heat and through December snow. The shoes are brown and have thick soles; the right one is shaped differently from the left. They are not particularly stylish, but were specially molded to suit Mr. Frenkel’s disfigured right foot, affected by the polio that he contracted as a child.

abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund appeal; Reesa Kashuk and Chloe Olewitz, eight-year-olds, are running hot chocolate and sugar cookie stand in West Village, and are donating their proceeds to fund; photo (M)
snippet: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund appeal; Reesa Kashuk and Chloe Olewitz, eight-year-olds, are running hot chocolate and sugar cookie stand in West Village, and are donating their proceeds to fund; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Chloe Olewitz and Reesa Kashuk, a pair of 8-year-old best friends from Manhattan, set up shop outside One University Place yesterday, with a good product and a good cause.

headline.main: Sidewalk Salesgirls With Golden Hearts
headline.print_headline: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Sidewalk Salesgirls With Golden Hearts

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

abstract: Sunday begins the 97th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign. Since 1912, the fund has provided direct assistance to those in distress.
snippet: Sunday begins the 97th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign. Since 1912, the fund has provided direct assistance to those in distress.
lead_paragraph: Sunday begins the 97th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign. Since 1912, the fund has provided direct assistance to children, families and the elderly in New York. Daily articles will appear in the paper and online through Feb. 6, illustrating the difference that even a modest amount of money can make in easing the struggles of poverty.

headline.main: Neediest Cases Fund Offers Relief in Homes Where Worry Lives
headline.print_headline: Neediest Cases Fund Offers Relief in Homes Where Worry Lives

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: Joe and Catherine Cossentino of Queens have struggled since he learned he had a severe heart ailment and both lost their jobs.
snippet: Joe and Catherine Cossentino of Queens have struggled since he learned he had a severe heart ailment and both lost their jobs.
lead_paragraph: She started working at Brooks Brothers in 1977, in accounts payable; he in 1979, in purchasing. They made eyes in the elevator. He looked for reasons to borrow envelopes. Their first date was on Feb. 14, 1980. Less than two years later, in his best suit  solid navy, flannel, three-piece  he proposed under the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center.

headline.main: Hit With a Double Crisis, and Coming Back Slowly
headline.print_headline: Hit With a Double Crisis, And Coming Back Slowly

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: The Neediest Cases Fund helps a single mother with four young children furnish their new home.
snippet: The Neediest Cases Fund helps a single mother with four young children furnish their new home.
lead_paragraph: Tatiana Ricardo is a single mother of four children, including two who have special needs. Her days mostly consist of cooking, cleaning, doing laundry and taking the children to and from school. But to Ms. Ricardo, “It’s all worth it. I’d do anything for them.” Someday, she says, she would like to open her own day care center.

abstract: Some donors who find unusual ways to raise money for New York Times Neediest Cases Fund (M)
snippet: Some donors who find unusual ways to raise money for New York Times Neediest Cases Fund (M)
lead_paragraph: At 66, Juergen R. Goldhagen has let his hair grow, tying it into a ponytail. At first it was for fun, to inject a spark of style, even some Samsonesque vigor, into his post-retirement life. But he soon recognized an added benefit: a year's savings on haircuts could be sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help the poor.

headline.main: From Skipping Haircuts or Coffee, Some Find Unusual Means for Giving
headline.print_headline: From Skipping Haircuts or Coffee, Some Find Unusual Means for Giving

abstract: Heather Ferreira poured every cent that she made at part-time and freelance jobs into creating a retro children’s television project. Unemployment temporarily derailed her plans.
snippet: Heather Ferreira poured every cent that she made at part-time and freelance jobs into creating a retro children’s television project. Unemployment temporarily derailed her plans.
lead_paragraph: Heather Ferreira did not choose a career in entertainment as much as it chose her.

headline.main: Nurturing a Vision Through the Good Times and Bad
headline.print_headline: Nurturing a Vision Through the Good Times and Bad

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: Drug dealers roam his building after dark, and bursts of gunfire are not uncommon. When the heat shuts off late at night, his family huddles for warmth. But after a period of homelessness, Mitchell T. treasures his small, private space.   A decade ago, at 26, he had a steady income and unmarred optimism. But he lost his job as a security guard in 1986 and had to abandon his apartment. He and his girlfriend moved in with relatives, but eventually they had to leave. Penniless, they were placed in a single-room-occupancy hotel in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Drug dealers roam his building after dark, and bursts of gunfire are not uncommon. When the heat shuts off late at night, his family huddles for warmth. But after a period of homelessness, Mitchell T. treasures his small, private space.
